{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3498954,"name":"J.s","username":"JaySlinky","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/aca169/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-01T15:40:05.658Z","cooked":"

Hello

I have an issue where i keep getting this error but I dont know how to fix it. I’m using the swerve with pathplanner code from ctre. my code deploys but while im in auto the wheels jerk erratically.

  • Auto builder has already been configured. This is likely in error.

  • Error at com.pathplanner.lib.auto.AutoBuilder.configure(AutoBuilder.java:72): Auto builder has already been configured. This is likely in error.

  • at com.pathplanner.lib.auto.AutoBuilder.configure(AutoBuilder.java:72)

  • at frc.robot.subsystems.CommandSwerveDrivetrain.configureAutoBuilder(CommandSwerveDrivetrain.java:112)

  • at frc.robot.subsystems.CommandSwerveDrivetrain.(CommandSwerveDrivetrain.java:54)

  • at frc.robot.generated.TunerConstants.createDrivetrain(TunerConstants.java:199)

  • at frc.robot.RobotContainer.(RobotContainer.java:31)

  • at frc.robot.Robot.(Robot.java:17)

  • at edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.RobotBase.runRobot(RobotBase.java:370)

  • at edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.RobotBase.startRobot(RobotBase.java:510)

  • at frc.robot.Main.main(Main.java:13)

This is my code

Hello,
It would appear that you have accidentally created multiple instances of RobotContainer. Once as a static call within the class and again with the call to the Robot constructor from Main. This is causing AutoBuilder to configure multiple times and is likely the cause of the strange wheel movement.

public class RobotContainer {
    public static RobotContainer robotContainer = new RobotContainer();

That is call 1.

  public static void main(String... args) {
    RobotBase.startRobot(Robot::new);
  }

  public Robot() {
    m_robotContainer = new RobotContainer();
  }

And that is call 2 (Note that main comes from Main.Java and the constructor comes from Robot.Java).
There are 2 ways to solve this issue.
1: Remove the first call. (Removing the static RobotContainer created within RobotContainer).
or
2: Change the constructor of RobotContainer to be private and remove the creation of a RobotContainer object from the Robot constructor. This would ensure that this issue doesn’t arise again.
Personally, my team uses solution 1, though solution 2 is technically better as it ensures that no one could accidently create a second RobotContainer by accident.
It is up to personal preference which solution you chose.

Thank you so very much. This fixed my issue completely. I am so very grateful
